articles.headline: For Charter Communications Chief, Time Warner Cable Is a Long-Sought Prize
articles.snippet: With last week’s cable deal, Thomas M. Rutledge stands to become one of the most powerful people in the Internet and television industries.
articles.abstract: With last week’s cable deal, Thomas M. Rutledge stands to become one of the most powerful people in the Internet and television industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — Thomas M. Rutledge declared victory last week when Charter Communications struck a $56.7 billion deal to acquire its much larger rival Time Warner Cable.

articles.headline: For Swapped Taliban Prisoners From Guantánamo Bay, Few Doors to Exit Qatar
articles.snippet: As the United States pressed Qatar for a six-month travel ban for the former Guantánamo detainees exchanged for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, no countries appeared eager to let them in.
articles.abstract: As the United States pressed Qatar for a six-month travel ban for the former Guantánamo detainees exchanged for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, no countries appeared eager to let them in.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two of them are accused of mass murders. Another defended the killings of foreigners. One has been described by the United States military as an opium drug lord and an associate of Osama bin Laden. Another was a top official in the feared intelligence service of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar.

articles.headline: Prices Are Down, but Saudis Keep Oil Flowing
articles.snippet: The change is upending the traditional market dynamics that have influenced the direction of oil prices for decades.
articles.abstract: The change is upending the traditional market dynamics that have influenced the direction of oil prices for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The international cartel of oil producers has long followed the same basic strategy. When the market was soft, the group slashed production to raise prices.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Use of Tasers Is Scrutinized After Walter Scott Shooting
articles.snippet: Records show that a North Charleston, S.C., police officer, who fatally shot Mr. Scott in April, like others in the department frequently made use of a Taser.
articles.abstract: Records show that a North Charleston, S.C., police officer, who fatally shot Mr. Scott in April, like others in the department frequently made use of a Taser.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — It was late on a Sunday in May 2014 when Officer Michael T. Slager of the North Charleston Police Department stood outside an apartment and faced off with a man whose fists, he said, were clenched as he assumed an “aggressive stance.” Mr. Slager, who said he had just watched the man assault a roommate, forced him to the ground with a five-second burst of electricity from a Taser.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Manny Fernandez and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: ‘Viagra for Women’ Gets Push for F.D.A. Approval
articles.snippet: A campaign for a drug that aims to restore lost libido accuses the Food and Drug Administration of gender bias for approving Viagra and 25 other drugs to help men have sex, but none for women.
articles.abstract: A campaign for a drug that aims to restore lost libido accuses the Food and Drug Administration of gender bias for approving Viagra and 25 other drugs to help men have sex, but none for women.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is sexual desire a human right? And are women entitled to a little pink pill to help them feel it?

articles.headline: Motorola’s Antitrust Lawsuit May Head to Top Court
articles.snippet: Years after the mobile device company was a corporate victim of a price-fixing scheme, the Supreme Court might take up the case.
articles.abstract: Years after the mobile device company was a corporate victim of a price-fixing scheme, the Supreme Court might take up the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: The evidence is compelling. The cartel of Asian electronics makers worked for more than five years to set the prices of liquid-crystal display screens used in computers and cellphones. They gathered for monthly meetings in private conference rooms at luxury hotels.

articles.headline: A Gap in Surveillance, but Ways Around It
articles.snippet: The fact that Congress allowed counterterrorism laws to lapse is an extraordinary moment in the story of the tensions between post-9/11 policies and privacy rights.
articles.abstract: The fact that Congress allowed counterterrorism laws to lapse is an extraordinary moment in the story of the tensions between post-9/11 policies and privacy rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first time since the aftermath of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Americans are again free to place phone calls — to friends, lovers, business associates, political groups, doctors and pizza restaurants — without having logs of those contacts vacuumed up in bulk by the National Security Agency.

articles.headline: Academics Seek a Big Splash
articles.snippet: The benefits of generating media attention may be skewing research studies and broadening their findings.
articles.abstract: The benefits of generating media attention may be skewing research studies and broadening their findings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each July, many of the top economists in the world gather in Cambridge, Mass., at a conference hosted by the National Bureau of Economic Research. While the work they present comes in all shapes and sizes, from the highly technical to the trendy and provocative, the coveted first day of a key weeklong session is given over to research that will make a media splash.

articles.headline: Intel Agrees to Buy Altera for $16.7 Billion
articles.snippet: The deal would be the latest in a wave of consolidation as chip makers look to increase their scale and product offerings.
articles.abstract: The deal would be the latest in a wave of consolidation as chip makers look to increase their scale and product offerings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Computers stuffed with superfast chips are going everywhere: home appliances, cars, smartphones and giant data centers. This creates rich opportunities for makers of semiconductors, vastly increasing the number of places they can sell ever-smaller chips.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and Chad Bray
